title: Moving with MG

content: Moving into a new home is often described as a fresh start. But when you live with myasthenia gravis (MG), it can feel more like a marathon you didn’t train for.

I recently made a big move. While I was thrilled about settling into a new space, I underestimated how much it would take out of me. Between juggling a full-time job and desperately trying to rest in between, I could barely prepare for the move.

Chronic fatigue made its presence known, loud and clear. I held up better than expected during the actual move. My body somehow powered through the physical labor, adrenaline, and necessity. But after the boxes were partially unpacked, the moving truck was gone, and I sat in my new room, everything really hit me.
I crashed. Hard. It took me weeks to get my energy and strength back. That experience reminded me that when I make it through the hard part, recovery is just as important.

content: Here are some hard-earned tips to help protect your energy, muscles, and peace of mind for your next move, or taxing chore:
Plan Early, Rest Often

If you know a move is approaching, start doing things early on. I started by decluttering each room. It took a few days to complete, but I took my time, decluttering each drawer, closet, and space slowly. I took the same approach to packing. I started with common areas like the living room, kitchen, and restroom. I packed on weekends because I didn’t have to work and I had more energy. Remember, your energy is a limited resource – use it wisely. Create a plan that works best with your schedule and body.
Delegate Everything You Can
Yes, everything.

Hire help if it’s within your budget, or recruit friends and family to help with the heavy lifting, packing, and transport. Save your energy for directing where items should go, organizing, and keeping everything on track. My goal during the move was self-preservation. I had a few moments where I moved items that were way too heavy because I was impatient. I felt the pain in my muscles the next few days.

sections.heading: Pack With Accessibility in Mind
content: Have a box dedicated to your “MG Essentials.” Include your medications, medical supplies, comfy outfits, heating pads, cooling towels, hydration aids, snacks, and other comfort items. Make sure you have them labeled and easy to access. It takes a while to unpack, and this method will ensure you can get to your essentials easily.
Prepare Your Rest Zones First

The bed gets made first. Not the kitchen, not the wifi, but your rest space. You’ll thank yourself immensely during your recovery. You need a safe, comfy place to retreat when MG symptoms creep in after a long move process. I unpacked my bedroom and bathroom essentials first. I also didn’t want to risk constantly tripping over boxes in the way.
Listen to Your Body After the Move
This is where I messed up.

After my move, I felt like superwoman. I felt unstoppable – until I had to stop. Delayed fatigue hit me like a truck. It took weeks to feel like myself again. Your body may be running on adrenaline during the chaos, but once it calms down, MG symptoms may come back with a vengeance. It’s important to prioritize naps, hydration, and minimal exertion. Healing takes a lot of work, too.

sections.heading: Be Proud of Yourself
content: Moving with a neuromuscular condition is a huge accomplishment. Take a moment to be proud of yourself. You honored your limits, got through the tough parts, and found a way to settle into your new space.
It might not seem like it to the outside world, but that’s something worth being proud of.

Living with MG means you move through life a little differently. That includes literal moves, too. It’s OK to take your time, rely on others, and let go of the idea that everything has to be done perfectly. It’s OK if boxes remain unpacked. Your health and energy matter more. Remember to rest, recalibrate, and restore.
Photo Credit: Moment/Getty Images
